title: House Republicans Are Already Voting On Anti-Abortion Bills As GOP Eyes Even More Restrictions
description: The House will vote on two abortion-related bills Wednesday as state legislatures start convening to take up other restrictions.

The newly Republican-controlled House will kick off its session Wednesday with a series of votes that include two anti-abortion measures which, while certain to fail in the Senate, are part of a broader push by the GOP at the federal and state level to further restrict abortion in 2023 even after voters came out in support of the procedure during the midterms.
House Speaker Kevin McCarthy gives a speech in Washington, DC on January 7.Anadolu Agency via Getty Images

Key Facts


The House will consider a resolution Wednesday that condemns attacks on anti-abortion rights facilities, as well as a “born-alive” measure that would require healthcare for fetuses who survive failed abortion attempts (even though such instances are exceedingly rare).



The votes—among the first that lawmakers will hold after its new session convened last week—come after anti-abortion activist groups sent a letter to House GOP lawmakers urging them to “pursue a robust pro-life agenda” and take stronger action against abortion, including passing a national six-week abortion ban and banning interstate delivery of abortion pills.



A number of Republican-controlled state legislatures that are now convening for legislative sessions have announced intentions to consider anti-abortion legislation, including a bill in Texas that would rescind tax breaks for companies that fund employee abortions and a 15-week ban in Virginia.



Medication abortion is expected to be a significant focus of lawmakers’ efforts, including a proposed bill in Missouri to prohibit abortion pills from being delivered into the state and a bill in Georgia requiring in-person exams before pills can be prescribed.


There may also be efforts to directly punish people who use abortion pills: Vox reports an effort is underway in Texas to allow civil lawsuits against anyone who’s terminated a pregnancy using abortion pills, and lawmakers in Oklahoma have already asked the state’s Attorney General to clarify whether someone who’s terminated their own pregnancy using abortion pills could be charged with murder.




What To Watch For
If these bills will actually pass. Lawmakers last year took up a number of high-profile abortion restriction bills that ultimately failed, as even Republican lawmakers often had conflicting views on how far abortion bans should go and what exemptions should be allowed. The House’s efforts to pass anti-abortion legislation on the federal level are all but certain to fail, given the Democratic majority in the Senate and President Joe Biden’s veto power.
Big Number
60%. That’s the share of voters who said abortion should be legal in all or most cases as of September, according to a Wall Street Journal poll, in line with other polls showing a majority of Americans do not want the procedure to be banned.

Contra
Some Republicans have railed against the party continuing to focus on abortion after it cost the GOP in the midterms. “We learned nothing from the midterms if this is how we're going to operate in the first week. Millions of women across the board were angry over overturning Roe v. Wade.” Rep. Nancy Mace (R-S.C.) told Politico about the House’s anti-abortion votes, saying there should be a “balance between protecting women's rights and the right to life,” but “what we're doing this week is paying lip service to life.”
Key Background
The Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade and the federal right to an abortion in June, setting off a wave of state-level abortion bans nationwide and sparking widespread anger among Americans in support of abortion rights. That opposition to the court’s ruling was reflected at the ballot box, with Americans in six states voting in favor of abortion rights in abortion-related ballot measures, even in conservative-leaning states like Kansas, Montana and Kentucky. Abortion was also viewed as a factor behind the GOP failing to secure the “red wave” of Republican wins that had been anticipated, and Democrats won many races with particularly high stakes for abortion rights, such as gubernatorial races in Michigan and Pennsylvania. The GOP’s renewed interest in abortion restrictions now that the midterms are over comes even as many candidates had backtracked on publicly criticizing abortion on the campaign trail, given the political opposition to abortion restrictions, with some even changing their campaign websites to erase previous staunchly anti-abortion stances.
